repnme.cdata!: Timor Leste - Emergency School Readiness Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey satisfactory project
            outcomes, likely sustainability, with only modest
            institutional development impacts. Among the lessons
            learned, it is suggested the Bank's emergency
            procedures, i.e., Operational Directive 8.50, could be
            reviewed, to specifically differentiate post conflict
            situations from natural disaster emergencies, currently
            inadequately addressed in emergency lending. To this end,
            lessons further argue on the importance of project design as
            a balancing act between infrastructure development, and
            policy formation, for although infrastructure should
            necessarily take precedence, fostering institutional
            policies as well, (e.g., education) would define post
            conflict emergency needs. Overall, social mobilization and
            communications interventions should be targeted, for
            example, organizing school rehabilitation committees to
            participate in classroom rehabilitation could have been the
            objective, making rural communities the target audience, and
            selected individual promoters the delivery medium. Other
            lessons re-enforce the importance of monitoring project
            performance indicators; of ensuring the distribution of
            educational materials, possibly pilot testing proposed
            mechanisms; and, of including educators in the management of
            education projects, that is, from education policymaking and
            system management, to even organizational structure and
            infrastructure development issues.

2259441.trustfund:
TF023762-TFET - IBRD OPERATING COSTS
            ASSOCIATED WITH THE TRUST FUND FOR EAST TIM,TF040073-EAST TIMOR - EMERGENCY SCHOOL
            READINESS PROJECT,TF023834-TFET - EMERGENCY SCHOOL
            READINESS PROJECT

repnme.cdata!: East Timor - Emergency School Readiness Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Exactly because what previously existed
            has been swept away, East Timor has an historic opportunity
            to build a new, modern education system, relevant to its own
            needs and context, that meets both quality and affordability
            standards. The Emergency School Readiness Project is the
            first in a series of steps in that direction, concentrating
            on East Timor's most urgent short-term educational
            challenge, revitalizing its basic educational infrastructure
            with functional schools (primary and secondary), furniture
            and equipment, books and learning materials, and management
            support. The project aims at providing school-aged children
            and youth with education at the "basic operational
            level," meaning schools with safe and clean buildings
            having roofs and school furniture, textbooks and learning
            materials, and management support. There are five project
            components. While the first project component rebuilds
            school physical infrastructure, the second provides
            learning-teaching materials, the third mobilizes and
            communicates with the community, the fourth conducts school
            mapping and supports workshops, study tours, and preliminary
            studies related to policy development, and the fifth
            component strengthens the project management unit.
